facts.text: Writ Petition No. 39 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 39 of 1972. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Lakshminarasu appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshminarasu, for the petitioner. L. Mukhoty and Sukumar Basu, for the respondent.

facts.text: L. Mukhoty and Sukumar Basu appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: L. Mukhoty and Sukumar Basu, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J. The District Magistrate, Burdwan, passed the order impugned in this petition on July 14, 1971

facts.text: District Magistrate, Burdwan passed detention order on July 14, 1971 under sub-sec. 1 read with sub-sec. 3 of sec. 3 of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act (President's Act XIX of 1970).

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Burdwan, passed the order impugned in this petition on July 14, 1971 directing the petitioners detention under sub-sec.  1  read with sub-sec.  3  of sec. 3 of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, being Presidents Act XIX of 1970, on the ground that such detention was necessary with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Detention necessary to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: ...on the ground that such detention was necessary with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on August 6, 1971 and furnished grounds of detention as required by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the order the petitioner was arrested on August 6, 1971 when he was furnished, as required by the Act. the grounds of detention.

facts.text: No dispute that Government of West Bengal and authorities took all consequential steps within prescribed times: reporting for approval, to Central Government, disposal of representation, Advisory Board reference and opinion.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that companysequent upon the passing of the said order the Government of West Bengal and the other relevant authorities under the Act duly took all companysequential steps, such as the reporting to and obtaining the Governments order of approval, reporting to the Central Government, disposal of the petitioners representation, referring the petitioners case to the Advisory Board and obtaining its opinion etc., within the respective times prescribed by the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner urged that first ground in grounds of detention was irrelevant, vitiating the order.

anchor.surface_text: Two grounds questioning the, validity of the said order and the detention thereunder were, however, urged by Mr. Lakshminarasu, appearing for the petitioner amicus curiae. The first was that the first ground in the grounds of detention was irrelevant and therefore vitiated the entire order.

facts.text: Petitioner urged undue delay in confirmation by State Government of detention order after three months.

anchor.surface_text: The second was that there was undue delay in the companyfirmation by the State Government of the detention order and the companytinuance of detention thereunder after the expiry of three months of detention.

facts.text: On 7-2-71 at 13-30 hours, petitioner and associates went to house of Shri Bibhuti Bhusan Ghosh of Ranchi Dhowrah, Police Station Kulti.

anchor.surface_text: The first ground in the grounds of detention runs as follows That on 7-2-71 at 13-30 hours you and your associates had been to the house of Shri Bibhuti Bhusan Ghosh of Ranchi Dhowrah, Police Station Kulti, and asked him to rub out the anti-naxalite slogans written on the wall of his house.

facts.text: Petitioner and associates asked Bibhuti Bhusan Ghosh to rub out anti-naxalite slogans on wall of his house; refused.

anchor.surface_text: ...and asked him to rub out the anti-naxalite slogans written on the wall of his house. Being refused you threatened to kill him.

facts.text: Petitioner threatened to kill Bibhuti Bhusan Ghosh.

anchor.surface_text: Being refused you threatened to kill him. Your such act terrorised the companymon public and as such they companyld number pursue the numbermal avocations of life.

facts.text: Threat to kill terrorised common public, prevented normal avocations, disturbed public order.

anchor.surface_text: Your such act terrorised the companymon public and as such they companyld number pursue the numbermal avocations of life. Moreover, it disturbed public order.

facts.text: State Government passed confirmation order on October 28, 1971, within three months from arrest.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the petitioner was arrested on August 6, 1971 and the order of companyfirmation and the impugned detention thereunder beyond the period of three months was passed by the State Government on October 28, 1971, that is within three months from the date of his arrest.

facts.text: Court held first ground relevant as threat to kill is offence under sec. 506 IPC, punishable up to 7 years, disturbing public order under Act sec. 3(2)(d).

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether threat to kill the said Bibhuti Bhusan Ghosh amounted to acting in any manner prejudicial to-the maintenance of public order as, defined in sec. 3  2   d  of the Act. ... Sec. 506 of the Penal Code provides that threat to cause death...

facts.text: Court rejected argument that ground 1 irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, therefore, be argued that ground No.  1  was extraneous or irrelevant to the objects set out in sec. 3 of the Act...

facts.text: Court held no undue delay in confirmation as passed within 3 months from arrest.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel, however, argued that though the decision of this Court have laid down that such an order of companyfirmation has to be passed within three months from the date of arrest... the order of companyfirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality... is affected.

facts.text: Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal cited, holding confirmation must be within 3 months or detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal 1 , a case under the Presidents Act XIX of 1970, this Court laid down that... failure to companyfirm or extend the period within three months would result in the detention becoming illegal...

facts.text: Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal cited, confirmation within 3 months from detention date legalizes continuance.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal 1 , Mathew, J., speaking for the Court, observed... if the order of companyfirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order number the companytinued detention thereunder is affected.

facts.text: Petitioner acted as amicus curiae.

anchor.surface_text: appearing for the petitioner amicus curiae.

arguments.court_reasoning: Threat to kill constitutes offence under Sec. 506 IPC punishable up to seven years imprisonment and disturbed public order, falling squarely within Sec. 3(2)(d) of the Act

arguments.claim: There was undue delay in the confirmation by the State Government of the detention order and the continuance of detention thereunder after the expiry of three months of detention; confirmation must be as soon as possible, not delayed until expiry of three months

anchor.surface_text: The second was that there was undue delay in the confirmation by the State Government of the detention order and the continuance of detention thereunder after the expiry of three months of detention. The first ground in the grounds of detention runs as follows

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in sec. 3  2   d  of the Act. Cl.  d , amongst other things provides that companymitting any offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life o

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmation order passed on October 28, 1971, within three months from arrest on August 6, 1971; precedents require confirmation within three months from detention, not sooner unless specified

arguments.claim: Threat to cause death under Sec. 506 IPC is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and qualifies as an offence under Sec. 3(2)(d) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 506 of the Penal Code provides that threat to cause death or grievous hurt or to cause an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine or both. That being so, the offence said to have been committed by the petitioner clearly was one of the offences enumerated in cl. d of sec. 3 2 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The threat terrorised the common public, prevented normal avocations, and disturbed public order, satisfying Sec. 3(2)(d); thus ground 1 is relevant

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 1 further alleges that the threat to kill the said Ghosh administered to him on account of his refusal to rub out the anti- naxalite slogans written on the wall of his house terror- ised the common public and as such they could not pursue the normal avocations of life and furthermore, disturbed public order. This assertion, coupled with the satisfaction of the other requirement of cl. d of sec. 3 2 , namely, the commission of the offence of threatening to kill, would bring the act in question within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as defined in sec. 3 2 . It cannot, therefore, be argued that ground No. 1 was extraneous or irrelevant to the objects set out in sec. 3 of the Act and in respect of which a valid order of detention could be made under the Act.

arguments.claim: Under Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal, confirmation must be within three months from detention or detention becomes illegal; here it was timely

anchor.surface_text: In Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal 1 , a case under the Presidents Act XIX of 1970, this Court laid down that it was essential that the appropriate Government should take positive action on the report of the Advisory Board... failure to confirm or extend the period within three months would result in the detention becoming illegal...

arguments.claim: Under Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal, if confirmation order passed within three months from arrest, legality of detention and continuance not affected; here it was timely

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal 1 , Mathew, J., speaking for the Court, observed... if the order of confirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order nor the continued detention thereunder is affected.

holdings.text: the offence said to have been committed by the petitioner clearly was one of the offences enumerated in cl. d of sec. 3 2 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 506 of the Penal Code provides that threat to cause death or grievous hurt or to cause an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine or both. That being so, the offence said to have been committed by the petitioner clearly was one of the offences enumerated in cl. d of sec. 3 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Threat to cause death punishable under Sec. 506 IPC with up to seven years imprisonment qualifies as offence under Sec. 3(2)(d) WBPVAA when commission disturbs public order; facts allege terrorisation of public and disturbance of public order

holdings.text: This assertion, coupled with the satisfaction of the other requirement of cl. d of sec. 3 2 , namely, the commission of the offence of threatening to kill, would bring the act in question within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as defined in sec. 3 2

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 1 further alleges that the threat to kill the said Ghosh administered to him on account of his refusal to rub out the anti- naxalite slogans written on the wall of his house terror- ised the common public and as such they could not pursue the normal avocations of life and furthermore, disturbed public order. This assertion, coupled with the satisfaction of the other requirement of cl. d of sec. 3 2 , namely, the commission of the offence of threatening to kill, would bring the act in question within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as defined in sec. 3 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ground 1 alleges threat terrorised common public, prevented normal life, disturbed public order; combined with offence under Sec. 506 IPC satisfies both requirements of Sec. 3(2)(d)

holdings.text: It cannot, therefore, be argued that ground No. 1 was extraneous or irrelevant to the objects set out in sec. 3 of the Act and in respect of which a valid order of detention could be made under the Act

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, therefore, be argued that ground No. 1 was extraneous or irrelevant to the objects set out in sec. 3 of the Act and in respect of which a valid order of detention could be made under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First ground relevant to Sec. 3 objects as it falls within definition of acting prejudicial to public order under Sec. 3(2)(d); does not vitiate detention order

holdings.text: The second contention also is no such as can be sustained

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, therefore, be argued that ground No. 1 was extraneous or irrelevant to the objects set out in sec. 3 of the Act and in respect of which a valid order of detention could be made under the Act. The second contention also is no such as can be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No undue delay in confirmation as order passed within prescribed time limits

holdings.text: the legality of a detention order or the detention thereunder would not be affected if an order of confirmation is passed before the expiry of three months from the date of detention

anchor.surface_text: This decision, thus, makes it clear that the legality of a detention order or the detention thereunder would not be affected if an order of confirmation is passed before the expiry of three months from the date of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Deb Sadhan Roy: confirmation required within three months from detention date or illegal; here timely

holdings.text: if the order of confirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order nor the continued detention thereunder is affected

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal 1 , Mathew, J., speaking for the Court, observed... if the order of confirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order nor the continued detention thereunder is affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Ujjal Mandal: confirmation within three months from arrest legalises detention and continuance; facts show Oct 28, 1971 confirmation after Aug 6, 1971 arrest

precedents.citation: Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: In Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal 1 , a case under the Presidents Act XIX of 1970, this Court laid down that it was essential that the appropriate Government should take positive action on the report of the Advisory Board, which action alone would determine whether the detention was to be terminated or compan

precedents.case_name: Deb Sadhan Roy v. West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Appropriate Government must take positive action on Advisory Board report to confirm or extend detention within three months from date of detention, failing which detention becomes illegal after three months
precedents.cited_holding: failure to confirm or extend the period within three months would result in the detention becoming illegal, the moment the three months period elapsed without any such confirmation

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal 1 , Mathew, J., speaking for the Court, observed at page 459 of the report as follows To put the matter in a nut-shell the State Government has power under the Act to detain a person without trial beyond a period of three months-, but limited to a period of on year. That power the State Government may exercise on receipt of the opinion of the Board that there is sufficient cause for the detention. When the State Government receives that opinion, it has still the option to exercise the power and to continue the detention beyond the period of three months or not.

precedents.cited_proposition: State Government must exercise power to confirm detention within three months from date of detention based on Advisory Board opinion, otherwise detention after three months lacks authority of law
precedents.cited_holding: Unless that power is exercised within the period of three months from the date of detention, the detention after the expiry of that period would be without the authority of the law

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if the order of companyfirmation has been passed, as it has been done in the present case, within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order number the

outcome.relief_summary: Legality of detention order and continued detention upheld; petitioner's contentions rejected

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 506 of the Penal Code provides that threat to cause death or grievous hurt or to cause an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life shall be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine or both. That being so, the offence said to have been committed by the petitioner clearly was one of the offences enumerated in cl. d of sec. 3 2 of the Act.

Therefore, if the order of companyfirmation has been passed, as it has been done in the present case, within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order number the

anchor.surface_text: Ground No. 1 further alleges that the threat to kill the said Ghosh administered to him on account of his refusal to rub out the anti- naxalite slogans written on the wall of his house terror- ised the common public and as such they could not pursue the normal avocations of life and furthermore, disturbed public order. This assertion, coupled with the satisfaction of the other requirement of cl. d of sec. 3 2 , namely, the commission of the offence of threatening to kill, would bring the act in question within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as defined in sec. 3 2 .

Therefore, if the order of companyfirmation has been passed, as it has been done in the present case, within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order number the

anchor.surface_text: This decision, thus, makes it clear that the legality of a detention order or the detention thereunder would not be affected if an order of confirmation is passed before the expiry of three months from the date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ujjal Mandal v. West Bengal 1 , Mathew, J., speaking for the Court, observed... if the order of confirmation has been passed... within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order nor the continued detention thereunder is affected.

Therefore, if the order of companyfirmation has been passed, as it has been done in the present case, within three months time from the date of arrest, neither the legality of the detention order number the
